_decoded_content.title: Enable Meltano to use an SSH Tunnel
_decoded_content.description:
Saw this thread on DBT slack https://getdbt.slack.com/archives/C0100SUQ0CW/p1652224126297119

SSH Tunneling via SSH itself is fairly straight forward as shown here https://www.ssh.com/academy/ssh/tunneling/example

If we wanted something more general, we could write a utility https://docs.meltano.com/concepts/plugins#utilities  maybe using something like https://pypi.org/project/sshtunnel/. 

The end result could be
`meltano run ssh-tunnel tap-postgres target-postgres`


Possible outcomes of this issue:
- Create a writeup for how to use SSH Tunnels with Taps/Targets
- Create a SSH Tunnel Utility
- Make an example / show it off of using the SSH Tunnel utility

_decoded_content.title: Helm-deployed Airflow does not have access to Airflow config file
_decoded_content.description:
### Problem to solve

When deploying Airflow using deployment tools such as Helm, configuration artefacts are needed at the time of deploy (e.g. `.env` files and `config.py`). These are generated by `meltano invoke` but are not accessible to users directly.

Meltano makes it easy to centralised configuration and to inject config artefacts (env vars and files) into a plugins context during execution with `meltano invoke`, but these generated files are cleaned up after the invoked process exits (to prevent secrets leaking). In order to provide the same benefits to plugins (services) that require config at deployment time (e.g. Airflow, Superset) we could provide a mechanism to export these config artefacts to a user-specified location on disk for use in deployment scripts and Helm inputs as part of a CI/CD pipeline.

### Target audience

Anyone using Meltano with service-based plugins that need deployment in production (e.g. Airflow, Superset).

### Further details

As part of setup for services like Airflow during `meltano invoke`, Meltano generates/populates Airflow-specific config files and environment variables from the Projects top-level `meltano.yml`. This is useful for local development and execution, however production deployment tools such as Helm require these artefacts at the point of deployment (usually at the end of an automated CI/CD pipeline). As `meltano invoke` does clean-up after any spawned processes terminate, these files (and the logic that generates them) cannot easily be accessed for use in production deployments. Exposing them via the CLI would allow users to benefit from Meltanos centralised config features even when using external deployment tools.

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

Meltano can be used to centralise config at all stages of development and deployment (not just locally via `invoke`).

_decoded_content.title: Consider an improved Python Base Image for Docker Meltano Images
_decoded_content.description:
### Problem to solve
Reducing security vulnerabilities in Meltano Docker Images to meet IT Security Guidelines.


### Target audience
This will be beneficial for all Meltano Users who use the Meltano Docker Images - especially helpful for Containerized implementations of Meltano.


### Further details
When scanning the Meltano Image for vulnerabilities (via AWS Container Registry - ECR), there are many security vulnerabilities listed. They mainly appear to be attributed to the Docker Python base image.

My security team would like to minimize the number of identified vulnerabilities, and the only way to do this is to change the python base image Meltano is built on.  


### Proposal
Having come across this article, https://snyk.io/blog/best-practices-containerizing-python-docker/, they appear to recommend alternative base images for Python. For example I am building a Meltano Python 3.8 Image, the recommendation is
python:3.8.12-slim-bullseye
I'm wonder if it is possible to have alternative Meltano Docker builds which I could pull with a more hardened base image?

I have tested and use the slim-bullseye by making my own Custom Meltano Base image and it seems to work well. The other advantage is that it reduces the size of the overall Docker Image.

Please Note: I really don't want to maintain my own custom meltano base image as I need to update a number of the other dependency files e.g. pyproject.toml. This makes my builds brittle and subject to build failure when there are updated Meltano releases.


### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?
Success for me would be less security vunerabilities.

I feel this could be done either one of two ways which aligns to @aaronsteers thinking as well.

1. Completely swap out the Python Base image with the slim Python versions as suggested by the Synk article.
2. Have alternative builds / variants Meltano Docker Images which use the slim Python image for the Meltano Base build.

### Regression test
(Ensure the feature doesn't cause any regressions)
- [ ] Regression build some Meltano Docker images to ensure TAPS and TARGETS still work
- [ ] Consider a phased deployed e.g. Option 2 first and then Option 1. In that way users can confirm the new slim python builds work for them.

### Links / references

https://snyk.io/blog/best-practices-containerizing-python-docker/

The attached file is my example [Dockerfile](/uploads/435de894cd04eef11959b31a7b3c7a4d/Dockerfile) for my custom based build of the Meltano Base using a slim-python base image.

_decoded_content.title: Freeze Gitlab docker images as stable, rather than continually updating
_decoded_content.description:
Blocks https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/merge_requests/2542

Before we can direct users to leverage our Gitlab-hosted docker images, we need to resolve a potential issue where `latest*` and `v1.xx.0*` images are apparently being constantly updated on every build to `master`.

Probably the solution is to have a more clear delineation between which images are "dev/test" images needed by later CI steps, and which images are "published/stable" images that can be relied upon by users with production workloads.

Notes:

- We can _optionally_ keep `latest` and `latest*` images linked to master CI builds, with the proper caveat/disclaimer to users that they are non-stable releases for the purposes of previewing unreleased features. (Not for production workloads.)
- Versioned images `*v1.xx.0*` should definitely not be updated continually with new `master` updates. The timestamp on those images reflects them being continually updated as of now.

_decoded_content.title: Specify required version (or range) of Meltano in `meltano.yml`
_decoded_content.description:
### Problem to solve
(Summarize the problem we are trying to solve in the form of we need to do [A], so that [B] can [C])

Early failure any Meltano task if the installed version does not fall in the supported range.

### Target audience
(For whom are we doing this? Include a persona)

Teams sharing a Meltano project.

### Further details
(Include use cases, benefits, and/or goals)

With new features being added to Meltano and the evolving schema of `meltano.yml`, it'd help in collaboration by hard-failing execution if the version of Meltano does not fall in the required range.

### Proposal
(How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey)

Similar to dbt's [`require-dbt-version`](https://docs.getdbt.com/reference/project-configs/require-dbt-version/).

```yaml
# meltano.yml
require-meltano-version: <string or array>
```

with the possibilities being:

* `"1.96.0"`
* `">1.96.0, <2.0.0"`
* `[">1.96.0, <2.0.0"]`

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?
(Define both the success metrics and acceptance criteria. Note that success metrics indicate the desired business outcomes, while acceptance criteria indicate when the solution is working correctly. If there is no way to measure success, link to an issue that will implement a way to measure this)

Users can specify a range of versions which their Meltano project support.

### Regression test
(Ensure the feature doesn't cause any regressions)
- [ ] Write adequate test cases and submit test results
- [ ] Test results should be reviewed by a person from the team

### Links / references

_Please note that this was taken from GitLab, to be changed accordingly_

- https://docs.getdbt.com/reference/project-configs/require-dbt-version/

_decoded_content.title: Helm chart Info is completely empty
_decoded_content.description:
Good day. I try to use your helm chart but it has no explanation to the parameters. 
During installation there are default values: 
```bash
image:
  repository: meltano/meltano
  tag: latest
meltano:
  database_uri: sqlite:///$MELTANO_PROJECT_ROOT/.meltano/meltano.db
replicaCount: 1
```

What is `database_uri` ? Is it external one, or internal one, created during helm chart deployment?

_decoded_content.title: installation error with Rancher (v2.6)
_decoded_content.description:
**The helm installation does not work with k8s on Rancher.**

Steps to reproduce: 
1. added helm chart to the helm repo list: `helm repo add meltano https://meltano.gitlab.io/infra/helm-meltano/meltano-ui`
2. deployed it with `helm install meltano-ui/meltano-ui --generate-name`

What is created well: 
- service pod created, seems to be working fine 
- ingress created

What is wrong: 
- error with deployment pod, status `Crashloopbackoff`. 
Error log: 
```bash
`meltano ui` must be run inside a Meltano project.
Use `meltano init <project_name>` to create one.
```

I set up ingress with my URL, and have visited it. The result is:
`503 Service Temporarily Unavailable`

Could you help me to understand what I am missing? Thanks!

_decoded_content.title: How to invoke and observe a container from another ECS or EKS container (and/or consider a "runner" plugin type)
_decoded_content.description:
This is intended to be a Research Assignment. I don't think we have an answer on this yet, and we likely would have to dedicate some time to resolve. If anyone already knows the answer(s) here, we may avoid having to dedicate time perform the research. :sweat_smile: 


### Background:

If we want Meltano to be able to support "prod" scenarios that launch new containers, we'll need a better understanding of the current capabilities and hurtles/challenges associated from launching a container from another container.

### Questions to answer:

1. From an ECS container, can we launch additional ECS containers and observe their output?
   1. If yes, what's the approach and general level-of-effort?
   2. In terms of observability, I think we'd at minimum need to see STDOUT and/or STDERR logs, whether the task is still running or stopped, etc.
1. Same question as above but for EKS instead of ECS.
1. Assuming a "yes" answer to either of the above, can this be done in a portable way? Either using a versatile 3rd party tool or library, or by standardizing on K8s interfaces and tools?

### Impact of research questions:

- If "no", and this is not a viable path (either impossible or if a solution is just too expensive/volatile), then we would _not_ expect `container_spec` #2205 to be portable and applicable to an already-running container in ECS or EKS.
- If "yes", and this is a viable path, then we would want to think about how `container_spec` could be made to run from an already-running container.

_decoded_content.title: Improve user experience with Docker and Compose file bundles
_decoded_content.description:
- The current Compose file bundle binds [the entire project directory as a volume](https://gitlab.com/meltano/files-docker-compose/-/blob/master/bundle/docker-compose.yml#L5-6). This can cause issues if the user has installed plugins in the host because virtual environments then get mounted as part of `.meltano/` and may not be compatible or depend on user-level Python packages, etc.

- The Docker file bundle includes a Dockerfile with the following lines

  ```dockerfile
  COPY ./meltano.yml . 
  RUN meltano install
  ```

  This means that if any plugins are defined inside of [`includes` files](https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2456), then they won't be installed during image build and require another `meltano install` after the container is created.

*TODO*: collate other DX issues with Docker and Compose

_decoded_content.title: Add Kubernetes Helm Chart to Documentation
Deploy squared projects to EKS with Airflow Orchestrator
_decoded_content.description:
As a pre-cursor to meltano##2149 (an 'official' Meltano helm chart), we would like to deploy our internal squared project to EKS with an Airflow orchestrator. This will not only support our internal data use-cases, but also serve as a platform to investigate future opportunities for closer integration between Meltano and common deployment tooling (terraform, helm).

### Overview

- [x] Create infrastructure: VPC, EKS Cluster, ECR registry, RDS database and EFS mount
- [x] Deploy prometheus for cluster metrics
- [x] Deploy community-owned Airflow helm chart
- [x] Deploy custom Meltano helm chart
- [x] Update CI/CD to deploy squared project to the above environment
- [x] Inject secrets from SSM into Airflow worker env
- [x] Configure EFS mount (for Airflow logs)

Going to punt the following in favour of merging with an MVP and improving incrementally:
- [ ] Create InitContainer for Database Administration
- [ ] Configure EFS mount (for Meltano logs)
- [ ] Modularise Layers (start with Infra)

_decoded_content.title: Trial install - AJ
_decoded_content.description:
Opening this issue to track a trial installation from instructions at: https://gitlab.com/meltano/infra/files-local-kubernetes/-/tree/main/bundle/infrastructure/local#setup

@kgpayne - You can see my log below in comments. I'm almost through, but looks like something is using port 5000 and I'll have to try again in a bit.

## Suggested updates

As going through the process, I had a couple suggested updates for your consideration:

1. The `deploy` folder is now `infrastructure`. What do you think of using the directory name `infra` for short? Would then be `infra/local` in place of `infrastructure/local` or `deploy/local`.
2. Can we update the top-level `README` with a link to the meltano file bundle install instructions?
3. I've confirmed the brew install commands below. Can we include those in the docs, perhaps next to each step?
4. Now that the environments feature has shipped, what do you think of using an environment-based approach to config, optionally combining with multi-file config, as in the sample below? Especially for the airflow overrides, a separate environment seems ideal for the local-k8 use case.
5. Since installing the file bundle also installs the main readme, what do you think of putting the file bundle install instructions first, and perhaps on the top-level readme, and then directing the user to the "main" installed readme for the next steps?

## Other observations

1. I'm not sure how/if "install" is able to consider environments, and so the special airflow pip_url definition may need to be a global setting.
2. I was surprised I could not find a way to add the file bundle definition directly to `meltano.yml` and then run `install`. Perhaps we just need to run the interactive `add --custom` option?

_decoded_content.title: Decide on input variables for `terraform-meltano-aws` and similar IAC modules
_decoded_content.description:
As a follow-on from the conversation in #2987 (internal), I thought it would be helpful to start discussing what configuration levels would be built into our Meltano IAC module for Terraform. To be sure that we have a specific-enough proposal without getting overwhelmed, I think we can describe this in AWS constructs _first_ and later translate these into the relevant constructs for GCP, Azure, etc.

## Functional data project configuration

These inputs drive core functionality of the Meltano project:

- `meltano_project_file` (str) - The path to a `meltano.yml` file to use in configuration of the environment. This would be [parsed by terraform](https://www.terraform.io/docs/language/functions/yamldecode.html) and may affect which resources Terraform creates, and how many. (Altering `meltano.yml` may require rerunning `terraform apply`.)
- `meltano_project_dir` (str) - The path to the Meltano project folder containing job definitions, dbt transforms, etc.
- `meltano_environment_name` (str) - The name of the environment to deploy, corresponding to a key in the `environments` entry in `meltano.yml`. This drives environment variable names and other configs as needed for the chosen environment. 
- `project_shortname` (str) - When AWS resources are created, they will be created with this text in the resource name.
- `aws_region` (required, str) - The region ID (e.g. `us-east-2`)

To keep the config DRY, most/all other configuration would ideally be migrated into _either_ the `environments` feature in `meltano.yml` _or_ the base plugin or utility config. Then `meltano.yml` (and possibly also `discovery.yml`) would be read as an input to the Terraform module's configuration.

## Optional, AWS infrastructure reuse and interop:

These inputs are all optional, and they allow the Terraform module to reuse existing AWS resources if desired:

- `use_existing_vpc_id` (optional, str) - The existing VPC ID to use. If null, a new VPC will be created.
- `use_existing_private_subnets` (optional, list(str)) - The existing private subnets to use. If null, a new VPC will be created.
- `use_existing_public_subnets` (optional, list(str)) - The existing private subnets to use. If null, a new VPC will be created.
- `use_existing_s3_logging_path` (optional, str) - The S3 path to use for logging purposes, when S3 log location is needed. If not provided, a new S3 bucket will be created.
- `use_existing_s3_artifacts_path` (optional, str) - The S3 path to use for storing temporary and long-term internal project artifacts, such as lambda function definitions, zip artifacts, and other internal project file storage. If not provided, a new S3 bucket will be created.

There may be more here but generally the config would follow the same pattern. In the first iterations, these may be all automatic - meaning we may not at first allow reusing existing resources. However, as the module matures, it should accept an increasing amount of interop and reuse with other environments, either for reasons of cost savings (RDS, K8 cluster, etc.) or corporate compliance policies (subnets, logging bucket, etc.). Most of these resources are free or have negligible cost, so probably would not need to prioritize reuse except for compliance reasons and for interop with existing application infrastructure.

_decoded_content.title: Document Deployment 'Tracks'
_decoded_content.description:
Meltano is incredibly versatile by design, meaning it can be used and deployed using a very broad range of tools and techniques. This breadth is clearly advantageous, but it can also mislead newcomers. We would therefore like to create 'tracks' in our marketing materials and documentation to reflect the archetypal usage scenarios:

- Personal Use; deploying Meltano locally and on free or low-cost hosting platforms.
- Commercial Use, Alongside Existing Data Estate; deploying Meltano to extend an existing platform, including to replace another ELT tool.
- Commercial Use, Greenfield; deploying a data platform from scratch using Meltano.

Both commercial use cases carry production level expectations for operational excellence (incl. logging, monitoring, alerting), reliability, performance, security and cost optimisation.

_decoded_content.title: Create AWS Deployment File Bundle
Create Local Deployment File Bundle
_decoded_content.description:
Having produced a proof of concept local deployment (#2910) we would now like to publish this as a [File Bundle](https://meltano.com/docs/plugins.html#file-bundles) for installation via `meltano add`. This includes:

- Publishing the Helm Charts for Meltano and Airflow
  - Helm expects charts to be hosted under plain http(s) urls. I intend to use GitLab Pages to fulfil this requirement.
- Publishing the Terraform Modules for Kind, Postgres and Docker
  - Terraform supports installing modules [directly from a git repository](https://www.terraform.io/docs/language/modules/sources.html#generic-git-repository)
- Creating a File Bundle that includes an `infrastructure/local` dir, `main.tf` file and other artefacts needed to launch the local deployment.

_decoded_content.title: Support Deployment to AWS Lambda (Serverless)
_decoded_content.description:
AWS Lambda provides a fully-managed (serverless) environment that includes both scheduling and compute (including docker). By supporting lambda as a deployment option and orchestrator for Meltano we can provide an easy onramp into the Meltano ecosystem for customers already on AWS but otherwise unwilling to host and manage a self-deployed orchestrator like Airflow.

Integration would include:

- A lambda-compatible docker container for Meltano
- A way to manage state utilising only serverless services (DynamoDB, Aurora Serverless, S3 etc.)
- A way to gracefully handle the 15min max execution time of Lambda.

There are several possible approaches to the final requirement:

- Include a new `--max-execution-time` flag that terminates the tap gracefully (emitting state) even when more upstream records are available. This allows meltano to sync data using successive Lambda invocations without being 'reset' to a previous state due to timeouts, but carries the risk that streams fall behind and never catch up with the upstream source.
- Parallelise pipelines using 'one stream per function' to minimise the risk of several streams in a single pipeline approaching the limit.

_decoded_content.title: POC Deploy Meltano locally with Terraform/Helm/Kubernetes
_decoded_content.description:
As a first step towards a supported production deployment method of Meltano on kubernetes, and to inform #2908, a local lab environment is necessary.

Desired outcomes of the POC are:

1. Deploying meltano and airflow end-to-end using terraform, helm and kubernetes
1. Evaluating the existing [Apache Airflow Helm chart](https://airflow.apache.org/docs/helm-chart/stable/index.html) for use with Meltano
1. Provide an example from which to build docs, demos and tutorials
